series.series.name: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE -- UPDATE

abstract.p: Update on Lower East Side, Dumbo and Douglaston Hill, three New York City neighborhoods recently added to state's registry of historic places (M)

block.p: Three city neighborhoods that flourished between the middle of the 19th and early 20th centuries were added to New York State's registry of historic places this month.

The Lower East Side Historic District, the largest of the three, was honored as the toehold in the New World for waves of working-class immigrants from Germany and Eastern Europe. It contains 508 buildings, including many tenements built between 1860 and 1900. The L-shape district runs between Allen and Essex Streets from Houston and Canal Streets, and extends five blocks west along East Broadway.
Three city neighborhoods that flourished between the middle of the 19th and early 20th centuries were added to New York State's registry of historic places this month.

The Lower East Side Historic District, the largest of the three, was honored as the toehold in the New World for waves of working-class immigrants from Germany and Eastern Europe. It contains 508 buildings, including many tenements built between 1860 and 1900. The L-shape district runs between Allen and Essex Streets from Houston and Canal Streets, and extends five blocks west along East Broadway.

The second-largest, the area known as Dumbo (Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass), was recognized as Brooklyn's cradle of manufacturing. The 24-block district has about 90 factories, many erected around the turn of the 20th century, that once housed leading makers of steel wool, machinery, corrugated boxes, soap and sugar.

And Douglaston Hill, a stately neighborhood in northeastern Queens near Little Neck Bay, was designated as a prototype of the commuter suburb. The four-block district contains 90 properties, including many Queen Anne, Colonial Revival and Tudor-style homes that were built in the years between 1900 and 1910.

''These are three great examples of places with historical and architectural value,'' said Randall Sawyer, a spokesman for the Office of Parks, Recreation and Development. The designations were issued June 9.

The nominations have been forwarded to the National Registry of Historic Places, which typically follows the state's lead, said Vicki Weiner, executive director of the Historic Districts Council, a preservation group.
Although the designations are largely honorific, the government provides tax credits for preservation work. ''It encourages proper stewardship of the buildings,'' Ms. Weiner said.
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE -- UPDATE
